paths.title: IUI With Partner Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using sperm from your partner - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Couples with unexplained infertility, mild male factor, or ovulation issues

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for donor sperm IUI evaluation
Comprehensive fertility evaluation and history for both partners to determine if IUI is appropriate
Complete fertility workup including semen analysis, ovarian reserve testing, and tubal assessment
Required blood tests for both partners to screen for infectious diseases
Doctor and patient choose between natural cycle monitoring or medicated cycle based on ovulation patterns and success rate goals
FOR NATURAL CYCLES: Patient calls clinic on first day of period; begin home ovulation monitoring with OPKs
FOR NATURAL CYCLES: Patient uses ovulation predictor kits daily starting around cycle day 10 to detect LH surge
FOR NATURAL CYCLES: Patient calls clinic immediately when OPK shows positive LH surge to schedule IUI
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Patient calls clinic on first day of period to begin monitored treatment cycle
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Days 2-3 baseline ultrasound and hormone levels to confirm ovaries are at rest
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Days 3-7 start fertility medication (Letrozole or Clomiphene) for 5 days
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Days 10-13 ultrasound and blood work to track follicle growth and endometrial development
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: HCG injection when lead follicle reaches 18mm to trigger ovulation in 24-36 hours
Partner provides semen sample on day of IUI; lab processes and concentrates motile sperm
Intrauterine insemination performed 24-36 hours after LH surge (natural) or trigger shot (medicated)
Optional progesterone support followed by blood pregnancy test 14 days after IUI

paths.title: IUI With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Intrauterine insemination using donor sperm - available as natural cycle (OPK monitoring) or medicated cycle (trigger shot protocol)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals, same-sex couples, or severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for donor sperm IUI evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss donor sperm IUI, eligibility, treatment options, and success rates
Complete fertility workup including tubal patency testing and ovarian reserve assessment
Required blood tests to screen for infectious diseases before using donor sperm
Required counseling session to discuss emotional and practical implications of donor conception
Choose sperm donor from sperm bank catalog based on preferences and genetic compatibility
If using known donor, complete legal agreements and additional counseling requirements
Order donor sperm vials (typically 2-3 per cycle); sperm undergoes 6-month quarantine and testing
Choose between natural cycle monitoring or medicated cycle based on ovulation patterns
FOR NATURAL CYCLES: Use OPKs to detect LH surge and call clinic for timing
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Day 2-3 baseline ultrasound and hormone levels
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Days 3-7 fertility medication to stimulate follicle development
FOR MEDICATED CYCLES: Monitor follicle growth and endometrial development
HCG trigger when follicle reaches 18mm (medicated) or detect natural LH surge (natural)
Lab thaws frozen donor sperm vials and performs sperm washing for IUI preparation
Intrauterine insemination performed 24-36 hours after trigger/LH surge using prepared donor sperm
Optional progesterone support followed by blood pregnancy test 14 days after IUI

paths.title: IVF With Personal Eggs & Partner Sperm
paths.description: Standard IVF using your own eggs and partner's sperm - includes protocol selection (GnRH antagonist vs agonist) and fresh or frozen embryo transfer options
paths.suitable_for: Couples with tubal factor, endometriosis, or failed IUI

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for IVF evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss IVF process, success rates, and treatment options
Comprehensive fertility workup for both partners including ovarian reserve, tubal assessment, and semen analysis
Required blood tests for both partners to screen for infectious diseases
Birth control pills (if using agonist protocol) and baseline suppression check
Choose stimulation protocol (GnRH antagonist vs agonist) based on individual factors
Patient calls clinic on first day of period to begin IVF stimulation cycle
Baseline ultrasound and hormone levels to confirm readiness to start stimulation
Start daily gonadotropin injections (FSH/LH) to stimulate multiple follicle development
Days 5-6 blood work and ultrasound to assess follicle response and adjust medications
Start GnRH antagonist injections when lead follicle reaches 14mm to prevent premature ovulation
Daily or every-other-day monitoring with ultrasound and blood work to track follicle growth
HCG or GnRH agonist trigger when 2-3 follicles reach 18-20mm diameter
Egg retrieval procedure performed 36 hours after trigger under conscious sedation
Partner provides semen sample; eggs fertilized using conventional IVF or ICSI
Monitor embryo development for 3-6 days with daily grading assessments
Choose between fresh transfer (Day 3-5) or freeze-all approach based on individual factors
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

steps.overview: Progesterone support and blood pregnancy test 9-14 days after transfer

paths.title: IVF With Personal Eggs & Donor Sperm
paths.description: IVF using your own eggs and donor sperm - includes protocol selection (GnRH antagonist vs agonist), mandatory counseling, and conventional IVF fertilization (preferred over ICSI for donor sperm)
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals or couples with severe male factor infertility

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for IVF with donor sperm evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss IVF with donor sperm process, success rates, and legal considerations
Complete fertility workup including ovarian reserve testing and tubal assessment (no male partner testing needed)
Required blood tests for female partner to screen for infectious diseases
Required counseling session to discuss emotional and practical implications of donor conception
Choose sperm donor from sperm bank catalog based on preferences and genetic compatibility
Complete legal agreements and informed consent for donor sperm use in IVF
Order donor sperm vials (typically 4-6 for IVF); sperm undergoes 6-month quarantine and testing
Birth control pills (if using agonist protocol) and baseline suppression check
Choose stimulation protocol (GnRH antagonist vs agonist) based on individual factors
Patient calls clinic on first day of period to begin IVF stimulation cycle
Baseline ultrasound and hormone levels to confirm readiness to start stimulation
Start daily gonadotropin injections (FSH/LH) to stimulate multiple follicle development
Days 5-6 blood work and ultrasound to assess follicle response and adjust medications
HCG or GnRH agonist trigger when 2-3 follicles reach 18-20mm diameter
Egg retrieval procedure performed 36 hours after trigger under conscious sedation
Lab thaws donor sperm vials; eggs fertilized using conventional IVF (preferred) or ICSI if indicated
Monitor embryo development for 3-6 days with daily grading assessments
Fresh or frozen embryo transfer followed by luteal support and pregnancy test
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

paths.title: IVF With Donor Eggs
paths.description: IVF using eggs from a donor - available as fresh donor cycle (synchronization required) or frozen donor eggs (no synchronization). ICSI required for frozen eggs, mandatory counseling and legal representation.
paths.suitable_for: Advanced maternal age, poor egg quality, diminished ovarian reserve, or genetic concerns

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for donor egg IVF evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss donor egg IVF process, success rates, and age considerations
Complete medical workup including uterine assessment and cardiovascular screening if over 45
Semen analysis and infectious disease screening for male partner or sperm donor selection
Required counseling to discuss emotional and practical implications of donor egg conception
Choose egg donor from donor bank catalog or recruit known donor based on preferences and matching criteria
Complete legal agreements with separate legal representation for all parties
Comprehensive donor evaluation including genetic testing, infectious disease screening, and psychological assessment
Choose between fresh donor cycle (synchronization required) or frozen donor eggs (no synchronization)
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Coordinate donor and recipient menstrual cycles using birth control pills
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Donor undergoes controlled ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Monitor donor's follicle development and administer trigger shot
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Retrieve mature eggs from donor under sedation
FOR FROZEN CYCLES: Thaw frozen donor eggs; FOR FRESH: Process fresh retrieved eggs
Fertilize donor eggs with partner or donor sperm using ICSI (required for frozen eggs)
Monitor embryo development for 5-6 days with daily grading assessments
Prepare recipient's uterine lining with estrogen and progesterone for optimal implantation window
Transfer selected embryo(s) into prepared uterus followed by luteal support and pregnancy test

paths.title: Double Donation IVF
paths.description: IVF using both donor eggs and donor sperm - includes genetic matching between donors to prevent 300+ genetic diseases. Highest success rates with 98% cumulative pregnancy rate after 3 cycles. ICSI required for optimal fertilization.
paths.suitable_for: Couples with both partners having fertility issues, same-sex couples, single individuals, or genetic concerns requiring dual donor screening

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for double donation IVF evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss double donation IVF process, success rates, and unique considerations
Complete medical workup including uterine assessment and health screening for pregnancy safety
Required counseling to discuss emotional and practical implications of using both donor eggs and sperm
Choose both egg donor and sperm donor with genetic matching to rule out 300+ genetic diseases
Complete comprehensive legal agreements for both donor gametes with separate legal representation
Comprehensive egg donor evaluation including genetic testing, infectious disease screening, and psychological assessment
Order donor sperm vials with 6-month quarantine period and comprehensive testing
Choose between fresh donor cycle (synchronization required) or frozen donor eggs (no synchronization)
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Coordinate egg donor and recipient menstrual cycles using birth control pills
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Egg donor undergoes controlled ovarian stimulation with gonadotropins
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Monitor egg donor's follicle development and administer trigger shot
FOR FRESH CYCLES: Retrieve mature eggs from egg donor under sedation
Process fresh or thaw frozen donor eggs; thaw and prepare frozen donor sperm
Fertilize donor eggs with donor sperm using ICSI (required for optimal fertilization with donor gametes)
Monitor embryo development for 5-6 days with daily grading assessments
Prepare recipient's uterine lining and perform frozen embryo transfer followed by pregnancy test

paths.title: Reciprocal IVF
paths.description: Shared motherhood - one partner provides eggs (biological mother), the other carries pregnancy (gestational mother). Requires cycle synchronization and allows fresh embryo transfer. 2024 legal changes removed enhanced screening requirements.
paths.suitable_for: Same-sex female couples wanting both partners involved biologically, LGBTQ+ couples seeking shared motherhood experience

steps.overview: Referral from primary care physician or self-referral to fertility clinic for reciprocal IVF evaluation
Comprehensive consultation to discuss reciprocal IVF process, shared motherhood options, and role selection
Complete fertility workup for both partners including ovarian reserve (egg provider) and uterine assessment (carrier)
Required blood tests for both partners to screen for infectious diseases
Decide which partner will provide eggs (biological mother) and which will carry pregnancy (gestational mother)
Choose sperm donor from sperm bank catalog based on preferences and genetic compatibility
Complete legal agreements for reciprocal IVF including parental rights and sperm donor use
Order donor sperm vials (typically 2-3 per cycle) with 6-month quarantine and testing
Comprehensive genetic testing for egg provider partner since they will be biologically related to child
Choose stimulation protocol for egg provider and synchronization approach for both partners
Synchronize both partners' menstrual cycles using birth control pills or hormonal medications
Day 2-3 baseline ultrasound and hormone levels for both partners to confirm synchronization
Egg providing partner begins daily gonadotropin injections for 10-14 days to stimulate multiple follicles
Gestational partner begins estrogen and progesterone to prepare uterine lining for implantation
Monitor egg provider's follicle development and administer trigger shot when follicles reach 18-20mm
Retrieve eggs from egg provider and fertilize with donor sperm using ICSI or conventional IVF
Monitor embryo development for 5-6 days while continuing carrier's endometrial preparation
Transfer selected embryo(s) to gestational partner followed by luteal support and pregnancy test
topic_refs: Fresh Embryo Transfer - Day Five (Blastocyst Stage)

paths.title: IVF With Gestational Carrier (Surrogacy)
paths.description: Using a surrogate to carry your pregnancy
paths.suitable_for: Absent/abnormal uterus, medical conditions, or recurrent pregnancy loss

steps.overview: Initial consultation to discuss gestational carrier pathway and assess medical necessity
Complete medical history, physical exam, genetic screening (CF, SMA, thalassemia), and infectious disease testing
Mandatory counseling with reproductive mental health specialist to assess readiness and coping strategies
Work with surrogacy agency or independently find suitable gestational carrier (ages 21-45, prior successful pregnancy)
Comprehensive evaluation including medical history, physical exam, uterine cavity assessment, and infectious disease testing
Clinical interview and standardized testing to assess mental health, support systems, and motivation
Independent legal representation for all parties to draft comprehensive surrogacy agreement covering parentage, finances, and medical decisions
Mandatory group counseling with intended parents and gestational carrier to establish communication expectations and boundaries
Gestational carrier undergoes trial medication cycle to evaluate uterine lining response to estrogen and progesterone
Create embryos through IVF cycle or select existing frozen embryos, with optional PGT-A genetic testing
Coordinate timing between embryo preparation and gestational carrier's uterine lining preparation
Begin estrogen supplementation to build uterine lining thickness, monitored by ultrasounds and blood tests
Add progesterone supplementation to mature the uterine lining and create optimal implantation environment
Carefully thaw frozen embryo on transfer day and assess viability (>95% survival rate expected with vitrification)
Transfer single embryo into gestational carrier's uterus under ultrasound guidance, typically painless 10-minute procedure
Gestational carrier continues progesterone support while awaiting implantation during the two-week wait period
Blood test for beta-hCG levels performed 9-12 days after transfer to confirm pregnancy
Continue fertility clinic monitoring with serial hCG levels and ultrasounds through 8-10 weeks of pregnancy
Graduate gestational carrier from fertility clinic to local obstetrician for ongoing prenatal care and delivery
Execute pre-birth legal orders and hospital protocols to establish intended parents as legal parents at delivery

paths.title: Sperm Freezing
paths.description: Preserve male fertility by freezing sperm
paths.suitable_for: Before cancer treatment, vasectomy, or advancing age

steps.overview: Physician or self-referral for male fertility preservation due to cancer treatment, vasectomy, or other medical indication
Complete storage consent forms, establish duration of storage, and document emergency contact information
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before sample storage
Provide detailed instructions for 2-7 days abstinence and collection technique to optimize sample quality
WHO 2021 comprehensive analysis including volume, concentration, motility, morphology, and vitality assessment
Collect initial sample via masturbation in private collection room or at home with proper transport within 1 hour
Process sample immediately, perform sperm preparation if needed, and assess post-thaw viability potential
Add cryoprotectant solutions and freeze samples using controlled-rate freezing or vitrification protocols
Collect 2-3 additional samples on separate days to maximize total sperm stored, especially for cancer patients
Test representative sample after thawing to confirm adequate sperm survival rates (>30% motility recovery expected)
IF NO SPERM IN EJACULATE: Consider TESE/micro-TESE or PESA procedures for azoospermic patients
FOR PREPUBERTAL BOYS: Store testicular tissue for future sperm production when conventional sperm banking isn't possible

paths.title: Egg Freezing
paths.description: Preserve fertility by freezing unfertilized eggs
paths.suitable_for: Delaying childbearing, before cancer treatment, or medical conditions

steps.overview: Physician or self-referral for female fertility preservation due to career planning, cancer treatment, or other medical indication
Blood tests for AMH, FSH, and antral follicle count ultrasound to evaluate egg quantity and predict stimulation response
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before oocyte storage
Start stimulation on cycle day 2-5 after confirming no ovarian cysts and normal hormone levels
Begin daily FSH/LH injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate multiple follicles, typically 8-12 days of medications
Add GnRH antagonist (Cetrotide/Ganirelix) around stimulation day 5-6 to prevent premature ovulation
Regular blood tests (estradiol, LH) and transvaginal ultrasounds every 2-3 days to track follicle growth and hormone levels
Modify medication dosages based on follicle growth rate and estradiol levels to optimize egg maturation
Precisely timed hCG or GnRH agonist trigger when lead follicles reach 17-20mm to complete final egg maturation
Fast for 8 hours before procedure, arrange transportation, and take prescribed pre-medications
Transvaginal ultrasound-guided needle aspiration under conscious sedation, typically 15-30 minutes
Embryologist immediately evaluates retrieved eggs for maturity (metaphase II) and quality under microscope
Mature eggs are immediately flash-frozen using vitrification technique with cryoprotectants for optimal survival rates
Monitor in recovery for 1-2 hours, receive post-procedure instructions and emergency contact information
Complete long-term storage consent forms, establish duration of storage, and document emergency contact information
Evaluate if additional cycles needed based on age, egg yield, and family planning goals (typically 15-20 eggs suggested per desired child)
Schedule annual review of storage status, confirm continued storage wishes, and process storage fees

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Partner
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos with partner's sperm
paths.suitable_for: Couples planning to delay pregnancy

steps.overview: Couple referred for embryo freezing due to career planning, cancer treatment, or other medical indication
Blood tests for AMH, FSH, and antral follicle count ultrasound to evaluate egg quantity and predict stimulation response
WHO 2021 comprehensive analysis of partner's sperm including volume, concentration, motility, morphology, and vitality
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before embryo storage
Start stimulation on cycle day 2-5 after confirming no ovarian cysts and normal hormone levels
Begin daily FSH/LH injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate multiple follicles, typically 8-12 days of medications
Add GnRH antagonist (Cetrotide/Ganirelix) around stimulation day 5-6 to prevent premature ovulation
Regular blood tests (estradiol, LH) and transvaginal ultrasounds every 2-3 days to track follicle growth and hormone levels
Precisely timed hCG or GnRH agonist trigger when lead follicles reach 17-20mm to complete final egg maturation
Transvaginal ultrasound-guided needle aspiration under conscious sedation, typically 15-30 minutes
Partner provides fresh sperm sample on retrieval day, processed using density gradient or swim-up techniques
Combine eggs and sperm using conventional IVF or ICSI based on sperm quality and previous fertilization history
Check for normal fertilization (two pronuclei) 16-20 hours after insemination or ICSI
Culture embryos in specialized incubators with time-lapse monitoring for 5-6 days to blastocyst stage
Assess embryo quality using morphological grading criteria and select highest quality embryos for freezing
Consider preimplantation genetic testing for chromosomal normality, especially for women >35 or previous pregnancy loss
Flash-freeze high-quality embryos using vitrification technique with cryoprotectants for optimal survival rates
Complete long-term storage consent forms, establish duration of storage, and document emergency contact information

paths.title: Embryo Freezing With Donor Sperm
paths.description: Create and freeze embryos using donor sperm
paths.suitable_for: Single individuals wanting embryos for future use

steps.overview: Single individual referred for embryo freezing with donor sperm due to career planning, cancer treatment, or other medical indication
Blood tests for AMH, FSH, and antral follicle count ultrasound to evaluate egg quantity and predict stimulation response
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before embryo storage
Meet with fertility counselor to discuss donor selection criteria, genetic matching, and psychological considerations
Choose donor based on physical characteristics, medical history, genetic screening, and personal preferences from sperm bank catalog
Confirm selected donor sperm has completed required 6-month quarantine with repeat infectious disease testing
Start stimulation on cycle day 2-5 after confirming no ovarian cysts and normal hormone levels
Begin daily FSH/LH injections (gonadotropins) to stimulate multiple follicles, typically 8-12 days of medications
Add GnRH antagonist (Cetrotide/Ganirelix) around stimulation day 5-6 to prevent premature ovulation
Regular blood tests (estradiol, LH) and transvaginal ultrasounds every 2-3 days to track follicle growth and hormone levels
Precisely timed hCG or GnRH agonist trigger when lead follicles reach 17-20mm to complete final egg maturation
Transvaginal ultrasound-guided needle aspiration under conscious sedation, typically 15-30 minutes
Thaw frozen donor sperm on retrieval day and prepare using density gradient or swim-up techniques for optimal quality
Combine eggs and donor sperm using conventional IVF (preferred for donor sperm) or ICSI if indicated
Check for normal fertilization (two pronuclei) 16-20 hours after insemination or ICSI
Culture embryos in specialized incubators with time-lapse monitoring for 5-6 days to blastocyst stage
Assess embryo quality using morphological grading criteria and select highest quality embryos for freezing
Consider preimplantation genetic testing for chromosomal normality, especially for women >35 or previous pregnancy loss
Flash-freeze high-quality embryos using vitrification technique with cryoprotectants for optimal survival rates
Complete long-term storage consent forms, establish duration of storage, and document emergency contact information

paths.title: Emergency Fertility Preservation
paths.description: Rapid preservation before cancer treatment
paths.suitable_for: Cancer patients needing immediate treatment

steps.overview: Immediate referral from oncologist with same-day fertility consultation to assess cancer treatment timeline and fertility preservation options
Emergency ovarian reserve testing (AMH, AFC) and medical history review to determine best preservation approach within time constraints
Expedited testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis with same-day results when possible, or proceed with quarantine protocols
Coordinate with oncology team to determine exact window available for fertility preservation before cancer treatment must begin
Begin gonadotropin stimulation immediately regardless of menstrual cycle day using luteal phase or follicular phase protocols
Add GnRH antagonist early to prevent premature LH surge, critical for random-start protocols
Daily blood tests (estradiol, LH) and ultrasounds to track rapid follicle development and adjust medications promptly
Maximize medication dosages and adjust protocols daily to achieve optimal egg maturation within compressed timeframe
Precisely timed hCG or GnRH agonist trigger when follicles reach 16-18mm (lower threshold than routine cycles) to maximize egg yield
Prioritized retrieval scheduling within 35-36 hours of trigger, typically 8-12 days after stimulation start
Rapid assessment of retrieved eggs for maturity with immediate decision on fertilization vs. egg freezing based on partner availability
If partner available, collect and prepare sperm for immediate fertilization; otherwise proceed with egg freezing only
Rapid decision between egg freezing vs. embryo creation based on relationship status, time constraints, and patient preferences
If fertilization performed, monitor embryo development with potential for Day 3 freezing if time-critical for cancer treatment
Immediate flash-freezing of mature eggs or embryos using vitrification with same-day completion
Complete essential consent forms and emergency contact information with streamlined process for urgent cases
Coordinate with oncology team to confirm fertility preservation completion and clearance to proceed with cancer treatment
Schedule follow-up consultation for post-treatment fertility assessment and future family planning when ready

paths.title: Ovarian Tissue Cryopreservation
paths.description: Experimental preservation of ovarian tissue
paths.suitable_for: Prepubertal girls or when time doesn't allow for egg freezing

steps.overview: Oncology or pediatric referral for patients who cannot undergo conventional ovarian stimulation due to age or time constraints
Comprehensive counseling with patient/family about experimental nature, risks, future transplantation procedures, and realistic expectations
Detailed medical history focusing on cancer type, treatment plan, gonadotoxicity risk, and surgical candidacy
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before tissue storage
Obtain IRB approval and research consent for experimental procedure, ensuring compliance with institutional protocols
Coordinate with oncology, anesthesiology, and pediatric surgery teams to optimize timing and minimize treatment delays
Anesthesia consultation, pre-operative testing, and surgical planning to minimize operative time and complications
Minimally invasive laparoscopic removal of ovarian cortical strips (typically one complete ovary or cortical strips from both ovaries)
Rapid histological assessment of retrieved tissue to confirm ovarian cortex quality and follicle density
Cut ovarian cortex into standardized strips (1-2mm thick) and prepare for slow-freezing or vitrification protocols
Freeze ovarian tissue using established slow-freezing protocols with cryoprotectants (DMSO, ethylene glycol) in programmable freezer
Test representative tissue samples for viability post-thaw and document follicle survival rates for future reference
Complete detailed storage records including tissue location, processing parameters, and long-term storage consents
Monitor patient recovery with attention to surgical complications and coordinate timely return to oncology care
Ensure minimal delay in cancer treatment initiation (typically <1 week post-surgery) and communicate with oncology team
Establish follow-up care plan for post-cancer recovery, fertility assessment, and potential future transplantation procedures
When ready for family building, counsel about ovarian tissue transplantation procedures, success rates, and alternative options

paths.title: Prepubertal Fertility Preservation
paths.description: Experimental options for children
paths.suitable_for: Children facing gonadotoxic treatments

steps.overview: Urgent referral from pediatric oncologist for child facing gonadotoxic cancer treatment before puberty
Comprehensive consultation with parents/guardians about experimental nature, risks, uncertain future outcomes, and ethical considerations
Evaluate cancer diagnosis, treatment plan, gonadotoxicity risk, life expectancy, and surgical candidacy with pediatric team

steps.step: Institutional Review Board and Ethics Committee
steps.overview: Obtain IRB approval and ethics committee review for experimental procedure, ensuring compliance with pediatric research protocols
Obtain parental consent and child assent (when age-appropriate) with detailed explanation of experimental nature and uncertain outcomes
Coordinate with pediatric oncology, anesthesiology, pediatric surgery/urology teams to minimize cancer treatment delays
Pediatric anesthesia consultation, pre-operative testing appropriate for child's age and medical condition
FOR GIRLS: Laparoscopic ovarian tissue biopsy or unilateral oophorectomy to obtain ovarian cortex containing primordial follicles
FOR BOYS: Testicular biopsy to obtain testicular tissue containing spermatogonial stem cells and early spermatogenic cells
Rapid histological evaluation to confirm tissue quality, follicle density (girls) or spermatogonial stem cell presence (boys)
Process tissue according to standardized protocols: cortical strips for ovarian tissue, small fragments for testicular tissue
Freeze tissue using established slow-freezing protocols with appropriate cryoprotectants for long-term storage
Test representative tissue samples for post-thaw viability and document baseline parameters for future reference
Complete detailed storage records and enroll in prepubertal fertility preservation registry for long-term follow-up
Monitor post-surgical recovery with pediatric-appropriate pain management and early mobilization protocols
Ensure rapid return to oncology care with minimal treatment delay, typically within 48-72 hours post-surgery
Establish longitudinal follow-up plan through pediatric to adult transition for future fertility assessment and experimental treatments
When patient reaches reproductive age, counsel about experimental options like tissue transplantation or in vitro maturation techniques

paths.title: Anonymous Embryo Donation Cycle
paths.description: Using pre-created embryos from anonymous donors
paths.suitable_for: Patients requiring donor embryos from anonymous sources

steps.overview: Referral for embryo donation due to inability to create own embryos from severe male and female factor infertility
Comprehensive consultation about embryo donation process, success rates, legal considerations, and emotional implications
Complete medical evaluation including reproductive history, pregnancy history, and assessment of uterine capacity
Required testing for HIV, Hepatitis B/C, syphilis, and other transmissible infections before embryo transfer
